newsitem.title: FRANCE: Chirac sees active role in spite of power-sharing.
newsitem.headline: Chirac sees active role in spite of power-sharing.

text.p: Marie-Benedicte Allaire

Gaullist President Jacques Chirac vowed on Saturday to stay active in governing France despite power-sharing with a leftist government as new Socialist Prime Minister Lionel Jospin began work on some urgent issues.

The conservative head of state, addressing a health cooperative conference in the northern city of Lille, ticked off a series of areas in which he intended to watch over things, ranging from holding France to its European commitments to expanding foreign trade and adopting new technology.
But Jospin dismissed the president's remarks as simply a reflection of the text of the French Constitution.

"The president described things as he sees them, and it is not surprising that he would define his role according to the Constitution. I also will act within the framework of the Constitution," he told the weekly Le Journal du Dimanche.

Chirac, in his first outing since his centre-right allies were swept from power in last Sunday's parliamentary election. said he had experience in power-sharing -- known in France as "cohabitation" -- and so was able "to appreciate the fundamental role of the president as guardian of our institutions."
Chirac served as prime minister in 1986-88 under late Socialist president Francois Mitterrand, who was widely credited with outmanoeuvring Chirac in a series of confrontations.

Chirac had spent the past week closeted in his presidential palace, publicly sighted just once, when television cameras captured a grim-looking president presiding over the first meeting of France's new leftist cabinet.
Jospin, meanwhile, got to work on several pressing problems.

He sent out word that he was still eyeing changes in a stability pact governing fiscal policy in the era of European monetary union and would soon disclose his stance on a controversial plan by carmaker Renault to close an assembly plant in Vilvoorde, Belgium.

A spokesman said the new prime minister would assemble his cabinet for a special meeting on Thursday, in preparation for his general statement of policy to parliament, which the Journal du Dimanche said would be on June 19.
The policy statement is intended as an outline of the new cabinet's ambitions and generally is followed by a parliamentary vote on a motion of confidence in the new government.
New Socialist Foreign Minister Hubert Vedrine conferred by telephone with his German and Polish counterparts on forthcoming diplomatic events, the Foreign Ministry announced.

German Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel and Polish Foreign Minister Dariusz Rosati telephoned from Warsaw, where Kinkel was visiting, to congratule him on his new portfolio and discuss a range of diplomatic topics, a ministry spokesman said.
He declined to give details but said Kinkel and Vedrine discussed a European Union summit in Amsterdam on June 16-17 and a Franco-German summit set for next Friday in Poitiers, France.
Jospin and Chirac will both attend the Poitiers summit, their first official joint outing.
The Franco-German meeting will take place among growing uncertainty over the conditions and timetable for a single European currency, in which Paris and Bonn are the key players.

During the election campaign, Jospin said he would impose conditions on Paris joining European monetary union, including a ban on new austerity measures for France to qualify for the euro and a requirement that Italy and Spain join from the outset.

The Amsterdam EU summit is expected to reach agreement on a new pact on EU institutional reforms, intended to update the Maastricht treaty, and French officials said in Brussels on Friday that they did not intend to delay the pact.
The meeting will also focus on the stability pact intended to assure fiscal discipline on the part of states participating in European monetary union, due to be launched in 1999.
During his election campaign, Jospin said he did not feel bound by the pact's terms and wanted to renegotiate it with more focus on employment.
There has been growing speculation in financial markets that the new government could cause tension with other EU states, especially Germany, and possibly delay the launch of the euro.
